title: Letters smuggled out of Holsworthy Internment Camp, March 1919 - Page 1

node.title: Letters smuggled out of Holsworthy Internment Camp, March 1919 - Page 1

und.value:
[Letter 1]

[Bolchevik message thrown over the fence from the Internees Camp at Holdsworthy during the time of the prisoner's strike there (March 1919).
It was wet weather at the time and the message was wrapped up in this way in order to keep it dry. There were a number of other similar messages thrown over but they were destroyed. The instigator of the strike was an internee named Heyne.
(To be kept wrapped as found)]
und.safe_value:
[Letter 1]

[Bolchevik message thrown over the fence from the Internees Camp at Holdsworthy during the time of the prisoner's strike there (March 1919).

It was wet weather at the time and the message was wrapped up in this way in order to keep it dry. There were a number of other similar messages thrown over but they were destroyed. The instigator of the strike was an internee named Heyne.

(To be kept wrapped as found)]

Transcript: 

[Letter 1]

[Bolchevik message thrown over the fence from the Internees Camp at Holdsworthy during the time of the prisoner's strike there (March 1919).

It was wet weather at the time and the message was wrapped up in this way in order to keep it dry. There were a number of other similar messages thrown over but they were destroyed. The instigator of the strike was an internee named Heyne.

(To be kept wrapped as found)]

title: Letters smuggled out of Holsworthy Internment Camp, March 1919 - Page 2

node.title: Letters smuggled out of Holsworthy Internment Camp, March 1919 - Page 2

und.value:
[Page 1]

Fellowslave

Do you know the facts in connection with the existing trouble inside of the fence? Here they are:
Two internees tried to escape but were stopped by the guard As a consequence the recreation grounds for the use of the internees were closed, and it was also prohibited to work the vegetable gardens of the prisoners
which were cultivated with much labor and now decreed by that terrible tyrann Holman to rot. Think of it, 4500 persons made responsible for the doings of 2 fellow internees! Is this not the act of a madman ?

Beware soldiers! This tyrann, which is starving us to-day, may decree the same fact to you to-morrow. Soldiers wake up! Do not let yourself be made tools for cruelly oppress those, who perhaps to-morrow will stand side by side with you to fight an common enemy ?Tyranny?
Hear the watchword of Europe awaking:

Long live Liberty, Fraternety, Equality and down with those who force us to slaves.
Think of it soldiers! Nearly 5 years behind the barb-wire cut off from all intercourse with the outside world, the satisfaction of man's natural needs made impossible and yet there comes a madman, who wants to starve us into submission, merely because we dared to stand up for our rights not to be made responsible for the doings of others
Be men! Go and have the facts about what is happening

[Page 2]

in the camp published and see that this tyrann Holman is where he ought to be, namely sunk into obliviousness.
What pitiful spectacle it would be, if this cowardly hypocritical madman would you to force us to submit to his devilish likings
Think before you act, and you will know what to do,

A.Slave

title: Item 01: Richard Blundell diary, 1 January-31 December 1915 - Page 32

node.title: Item 01: Richard Blundell diary, 1 January-31 December 1915 - Page 32

und.value:
1 January 1915
Friday

At Gordon on leave from

Camp. Went for swim

in Lane Cove River with

W.T.B. & Harry. Went to

Concord in aft. to see

Louis. Spent the evening

at Mrs. Williams.

Stayed at Gordon overnight. 

On leave from the

Light Horse Camp at

'Holsworthy' No. 4 Troop 

B. Squadron. Joined on

Dec. 14th, 1914

manner. The boys have got back from [Quarintine?] & they are bustleing through with the leave, the camp has been alive with rumours regarding the date of our departure, the very latest is that we have got our sailing orders & that the date is Xmas Eve, leaving Holsworthy for Sydney on the 18th. A squadron are going to Long bay for their musketry tomorrow & we go in when they arrive back that should be next Friday. We got a shock last Friday 4th at dinner when roast meat & potatoes came to light & the

title: Item 01: Joseph George Burgess war diary, 3 September 1914-11 February 1915 - Page 91

node.title: Item 01: Joseph George Burgess war diary, 3 September 1914-11 February 1915 - Page 91

und.value: a3895094.html strange to get letters away here in Egypt that should have reached me at Holsworthy as Vera's should have done. Pay day yesterday so it was quite a red letter day with us. 468 piastre what a figure equal to £4.160 An English sov is worth 97½ piastre & an Egyptian pound is worth 100 piastre I am quite up in this money now We can get any amount of leave here but I have not gone into Cairo yet but will do so next week we can go up the street here as we choose of an evening. I went up last night & with some

title: Item 01: Joseph George Burgess war diary, 3 September 1914-11 February 1915 - Page 50

node.title: Item 01: Joseph George Burgess war diary, 3 September 1914-11 February 1915 - Page 50

und.value:
a3895053.html

Monday 8.45. 14.12.14 Holsworthy                              I was home for my leave last week, the three days went before I had realiseded that I was on holidays. There is some hurry up just now, we are supposed to leave here on Thursday & to embark this week, the rumour says sometimes that we are to go to [Mourre?] park for a while. I hope so. I would just as soon put in Xmas in Sydney now that we have stayed so long; but I think we will be away somehow Stable [pickquiet?] tomorrow night, & Wed I will go into town if possible 15th Dec 14 Teusday 8.50 am Am feeling as lazy as possible
und.safe_value:
a3895053.html

title: Item 05: Kenneth Binnie miscellaneous papers, ca. 1916-1918 - Page 11

node.title: Item 05: Kenneth Binnie miscellaneous papers, ca. 1916-1918 - Page 11

und.value:
a6579015.html

Re Lt Kenneth Binnie

The Followin brief Summary of my

Father War Service were taken from

his 1916, 17, 18 and 19 Diaries

 

At the Outbreak of War Dad was managing

4D. Alan had won a scholarship to

Wxford and the rest of the Family

(including Struan) had gone to visit him.

 

Being a "man of the times" Dad was

extremely anxious to "Get Away" and

this was the subject of many letters

to his parents during 1915 beseaching

them to come home and relieve

him of his management duties so that

he could do this.

 

January 1916 saw him finally get his

wish and he enlisted as a

Gunner in the 7th Field Artillery Brigade

which were being formed at "the

Warren" /Camp near Holsworthy Tempe.

 

At the time he was courting my mother,

Linda Lloyd, who was a Sydney girl. and

Her family provided a welcome venue

for him on his frequent leave breaks.

Apart from leave breaks they looked after

their Horses, which were carefully selected,

cleaned the guns and Harnesses — which

he complained "rusted while you

watched".

 

The 7th F.A.B. embarked on the "Argylshire" for

England on 11th May - they had an enjoyable

& less eventful voyage with plenty of

good companionship from North Western
und.safe_value:
a6579015.html

good companionship from North Western

Apart from leave breaks they looked after

their Horses, which were carefully selected,

cleaned the guns and Harnesses — which

he complained "rusted while you

watched".

 

The 7th F.A.B. embarked on the "Argylshire" for

England on 11th May - they had an enjoyable

& less eventful voyage with plenty of

good companionship from North Western

a6579015h.jpg

Item 05: Kenneth Binnie miscellaneous papers, ca. 1916-1918

midships, the water is calm & it is swishing around the ship's bows in a business like way. Last Sat was an eventful day for us all & since then things have been moving. there has hardly been an hour but what has brought something of novelty for us. We knew that we were to get a move on sometime during Sat 19th at Holsworthy but it was 6.30 before we started to line up on the parade ground. Twelve of us under Serg. Trinder took about thirty horses (regects) to the Depot & then we rode back. All the others were muffled in their overcoats because of a storm which came across, as soon as we got into line we

und.value:
a3895050.html

Stanley Fender has been away all day, without leave, I wonder if he has scaled. Received a letter from Dos today, I must get in to see her on Friday if possible. Holsworthy Monday 7th Dec 7.15pm                          Well we have put in some streuous mounted work since we came to this camp, the horses are getting hard & are looking better, an extra feed at 10 oclock p.m. is sticking to them. My little mare is doing well, can go a bit, & is getting a bit cheeky she is like a pet foal in her
